Apple___Apple_scab.description: Fungal disease causing dark, scabby lesions on leaves, fruit, and twigs. Most severe in cool, wet spring weather.
organic_treatment: Remove and destroy infected leaves immediately
Apply neem oil spray weekly during growing season
Use sulfur-based fungicides every 7-10 days
Ensure good air circulation by proper pruning
Apply compost to improve soil health and tree immunity
chemical_treatment: Apply fungicide containing captan, myclobutanil, or mancozeb
Spray every 7-10 days during wet weather
Start treatment at bud break stage
Continue through petal fall and fruit development
Use a spreader-sticker to improve coverage
prevention: Plant scab-resistant apple varieties (Liberty, Enterprise, Freedom)
Avoid overhead watering - use drip irrigation
Rake and remove fallen leaves in autumn to reduce spore load
Prune trees to improve air circulation and light penetration
Apply dormant spray in early spring before bud break

Apple___Black_rot.description: Fungal disease causing fruit rot, leaf spots, and limb cankers. Infected fruit develops black, rotted areas.
organic_treatment: Prune out and destroy infected branches 8-12 inches below cankers
Remove all mummified fruits from tree and ground
Apply copper-based fungicides during dormant season
Improve tree vigor with balanced organic fertilization
Maintain clean orchard floor free of debris
chemical_treatment: Use fungicides containing captan or thiophanate-methyl
Apply during bloom and continue through fruit development
Spray every 10-14 days in wet conditions
Use a combination of protectant and systemic fungicides
Ensure thorough coverage of fruit and foliage
prevention: Maintain tree vigor with proper fertilization and watering
Prune annually to improve air circulation
Remove all infected plant material including mummies
Avoid tree stress from drought or nutrient deficiency
Monitor regularly for early signs of infection

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.description: Fungal disease requiring both apple and cedar trees to complete its lifecycle. Causes orange spots on apple leaves and fruit.
organic_treatment: Remove nearby cedar/juniper trees if possible (within 2 miles)
Apply sulfur-based fungicides starting at pink bud stage
Pick off and destroy infected leaves as they appear
Use neem oil sprays as a preventive measure
Improve tree health with compost and organic fertilizers
chemical_treatment: Apply myclobutanil, propiconazole, or triadimefon fungicides
Start spraying at pink bud stage and continue through summer
Spray every 7-14 days during wet weather
Use systemic fungicides for better protection
Rotate fungicide classes to prevent resistance
prevention: Plant rust-resistant apple varieties (Freedom, Liberty, Enterprise)
Remove cedar and juniper trees within 2-mile radius if feasible
Ensure good drainage around apple trees
Space trees adequately for air circulation
Monitor cedar trees for orange galls in spring

Apple___healthy.description: No disease detected. Plant shows normal, healthy growth with no signs of infection or stress.
organic_treatment: Continue regular care and monitoring
Maintain balanced organic nutrition with compost
Water appropriately - 1-2 inches per week
Apply mulch to conserve moisture and suppress weeds
chemical_treatment: No treatment needed
Consider preventive fungicide sprays in disease-prone areas
prevention: Regular inspection for early disease detection
Proper spacing for air circulation (15-20 feet)
Balanced fertilization - avoid excess nitrogen
Prune annually in late winter
Maintain clean orchard floor

Blueberry___healthy.description: No disease detected. Plant appears healthy with normal foliage and growth.
organic_treatment: Continue regular monitoring
Maintain acidic soil pH (4.5-5.5)
Apply sulfur if needed to lower pH
Mulch with pine needles or wood chips
chemical_treatment: No treatment needed
prevention: Test and maintain proper soil pH regularly
Ensure adequate drainage - blueberries hate wet feet
Provide 1-2 inches of water weekly
Use acidic fertilizers formulated for blueberries
Prune out old wood to maintain vigor

Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.description: Fungal disease causing white, powdery coating on leaves, shoots, and fruit. Thrives in warm, dry conditions.
organic_treatment: Apply sulfur dust or wettable sulfur spray
Use potassium bicarbonate sprays (1 tablespoon per gallon)
Spray neem oil every 7-14 days
Remove and destroy heavily infected shoots
Improve air circulation through pruning
chemical_treatment: Apply myclobutanil or propiconazole fungicides
Spray at first sign of disease
Repeat every 10-14 days until symptoms disappear
Use DMI (sterol inhibitor) fungicides for best control
Alternate fungicide classes to prevent resistance
prevention: Plant resistant cherry varieties when available
Space trees to ensure good air circulation
Avoid overhead watering - water at soil level
Prune to open up canopy and increase light penetration
Remove weeds and debris around trees

Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.description: No disease detected. Plant shows healthy foliage and normal growth patterns.
organic_treatment: Continue regular care and observation
Maintain proper watering schedule
Apply balanced organic fertilizer in spring
Mulch around base to retain moisture
chemical_treatment: No treatment needed
prevention: Regular inspection during growing season
Proper pruning to maintain tree structure
Ensure adequate spacing for air circulation
Water consistently - avoid drought stress
Apply dormant oil spray in late winter

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.description: Fungal disease causing rectangular gray to tan lesions on corn leaves. Can cause significant yield loss in susceptible varieties.
organic_treatment: Remove and destroy infected plant debris after harvest
Practice crop rotation - avoid corn-on-corn planting
Use resistant hybrid varieties
Apply copper-based fungicides if infection is severe
Improve soil drainage and plant spacing
chemical_treatment: Apply strobilurin fungicides (azoxystrobin, pyraclostrobin)
Spray at early disease detection - before tasseling
Use fungicide combinations for better efficacy
Apply at V5-V8 growth stages as preventive
Follow up application if disease pressure is high
prevention: Plant resistant or moderately resistant hybrids
Rotate crops - minimum 2 years without corn
Till under crop residue to reduce inoculum
Maintain adequate plant spacing for air circulation
Avoid overhead irrigation during humid periods

Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.description: Fungal disease causing small, circular to elongate reddish-brown pustules on both leaf surfaces. Most common in cool, humid weather.
organic_treatment: Plant resistant corn varieties
Remove infected leaves if caught early
Apply sulfur-based fungicides as preventive
Ensure good air circulation between plants
Avoid overhead irrigation
chemical_treatment: Apply triazole fungicides (propiconazole, tebuconazole)
Spray at first sign of pustules
Repeat application 14 days later if needed
Use strobilurin + triazole combinations for severe cases
Apply before tasseling for maximum benefit
prevention: Select rust-resistant or tolerant hybrids
Plant at recommended population densities
Scout fields regularly during cool, moist weather
Remove volunteer corn plants that can harbor rust
Practice good weed control to improve air flow

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.description: Fungal disease causing long, elliptical gray-green to tan lesions on corn leaves. Can significantly reduce yield if severe.
organic_treatment: Use resistant or moderately resistant hybrids
Bury crop residue through tillage
Rotate with non-host crops (soybeans, wheat)
Remove and destroy infected plant debris
Apply compost to improve soil health
chemical_treatment: Apply fungicides containing azoxystrobin or pyraclostrobin
Spray at early lesion development (V8-V10 stage)
Use combination products for better protection
Second application may be needed 14 days later
Target upper leaves which contribute most to yield
prevention: Plant resistant corn hybrids
Rotate crops to break disease cycle
Till under corn residue to reduce inoculum
Avoid planting corn after corn in same field
Monitor fields regularly during humid weather

Corn_(maize)___healthy.description: No disease detected. Plant shows vigorous growth with healthy green foliage.

Maintain proper fertilization with compost or manure
Ensure adequate water - 1 inch per week

Maintain proper plant population for hybrid
Ensure adequate soil fertility through soil testing

Grape___Black_rot.description: Serious fungal disease affecting grapes. Causes leaf spots, cane lesions, and mummified berries that remain on vine.
organic_treatment: Remove and destroy all mummified berries
Prune out infected canes during dormant season
Apply copper-based fungicides in early spring
Remove diseased leaves and fruit throughout season
Improve air circulation through proper canopy management
chemical_treatment: Apply mancozeb, captan, or myclobutanil fungicides
Start sprays at bud break and continue through bloom
Spray every 10-14 days during wet weather
Use combination fungicides for better coverage
Ensure thorough application to clusters and foliage
prevention: Remove all mummified berries from vine and ground
Prune vines to improve air circulation
Train vines to keep fruit off ground
Avoid overhead irrigation
Apply preventive fungicides starting at bud break

Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).description: Complex fungal disease causing tiger-stripe leaf patterns, berry spotting, and eventual vine decline. Often fatal to mature vines.
organic_treatment: Prune out dead and dying wood
Apply wound protectants to pruning cuts
Remove severely infected vines to prevent spread
Improve vine nutrition and vigor
There is no effective organic cure - focus on prevention
chemical_treatment: No effective chemical cure exists
Protect pruning wounds with fungicidal paste
Some growers report limited success with sodium arsenite (where legal)
Systemic fungicides may slow progression but won't cure
Focus on preventive wound protection
prevention: Protect all pruning cuts with fungicidal wound sealant
Prune during dry weather when possible
Disinfect pruning tools between vines
Maintain vine vigor through proper nutrition
Remove and destroy infected vines
Avoid unnecessary wounding of vines

Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.description: Fungal disease causing angular brown spots on grape leaves. Can lead to premature defoliation in severe cases.
organic_treatment: Remove and destroy infected leaves
Apply copper fungicides during growing season
Improve air circulation through canopy management
Use sulfur sprays as preventive treatment
Maintain vine health through proper nutrition

Spray at 10-14 day intervals during wet weather
Start applications at first sign of disease
Use strobilurin fungicides for severe infections
Ensure thorough coverage of foliage

Train vines to keep foliage off ground
Avoid overhead irrigation
Remove leaf litter and debris from vineyard floor
Plant resistant grape varieties when available

organic_treatment: Remove and destroy infected trees immediately to prevent spread
Control psyllid vectors with neem oil and insecticidal soaps
Improve tree nutrition to extend productive life
Use reflective mulches to deter psyllids
There is NO cure - focus on prevention and vector control
chemical_treatment: No chemical cure exists for HLB
Control psyllid vectors with systemic insecticides (imidacloprid)
Apply foliar nutritional sprays to support infected trees
Use antibiotics where approved (streptomycin, oxytetracycline)
Remove infected trees to protect healthy ones

Scout regularly for Asian citrus psyllid
Implement aggressive psyllid control program
Remove infected trees immediately when detected
Establish new groves away from infected areas
Support area-wide vector control programs

Start applications at first sign of disease

Apply copper fungicides preventatively before symptoms appear
Harvest tubers quickly if disease appears in field
Do not harvest or store tubers from infected plants

chemical_treatment: Apply mancozeb, chlorothalonil, or fluazinam preventatively
Spray every 5-7 days during cool, wet weather
Use systemic fungicides (cymoxanil, dimethomorph) for active infections
Tank-mix protectant and systemic fungicides
Continue sprays until vines die naturally or are killed
Apply pre-harvest vine desiccant to prevent tuber infection
prevention: Plant resistant potato varieties (Defender, Elba, Sebago)
Use certified disease-free seed potatoes
Ensure excellent drainage in planting area
Destroy volunteer potatoes and cull piles
Monitor regional late blight forecasts and alerts
Hill plants adequately to protect developing tubers
Allow 2-3 weeks between vine death and harvest
